Posts.Title: Mets during chemo? HeatherBLocklear heatherpalmerton

Posts.Content: May 4, 2009 08:35AM S3K5 wrote: Hi Enthused, Where are you located? Does your mom have access to a bigger cancer treatment facility? Usually, when a suspicious 'spot' is seen, a biopsy is done. Once it comes out positive for cancer, a MRI is recommended. MRI can detect even smallest spots. Based on this, the patient undergoes either a lumpectomy or a masectomy (depending on the tumor location,grade, etc). One day before the surgery, a dye is injected to locate the nodes (within the breast area). If these come out positive, then the II level of nodes are taken out (under the arm). In my case, I had one biopsy, MRI and then all lymph nodes under the arm were taken out during the same surgery (lumpectomy). Some patients will have to go a second time for lymph node surgery. If you don't get convincing answers, then please change the doctor. They have to explain everything before the procedure is done. I am in the medical field, hence it was easier for me to follow, but then I had a great surgeon too! Good luck with everything, Desi.

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2019 10:08AM S3K5 wrote: Hi, This is a great site for information for people facing Chemo and the side effects. I have gone through ACT in 2008 and now I am back with mets in bones and liver. After trying a few oral chemo regimens, I just started weekly Taxol. My oncologist/nurses at MSKCC were very helpful in educating me about dealing with side effects - the most important to me was avoiding complete hair loss and neuropathy. I thought I would add my experience here. MSKCC has a cooling system call PAXMAN from where I ordered the cooling cap and cover. The onco nurse helped me put it on and hooked me up to a cooling machine so I didn't have to change the cap every 20 mins. I am sure there are other cooling scalp methods that you could use instead of Paxman system, which is kind of expensive. By the way, these tips are available on 'Weekly Taxol" forum too: https://community.breastcancer.org/forum/69/topics/788735?page=356#post_5382385. For hands and feet they provided disposable ice paks over my fingers and toes (put on a pair of disposable gloves to keep them in place). Hopefully this will help minimize nail issues and neuropathy. I will find out if these cooling methods work for me in about 6 weeks. Everyone is different. According to my onco, it works for 50% of women in her care. Please keep this posting bumped up and please add any tips you may find to deal with this monster disease and the treatment side effects

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2009 01:24PM S3K5 wrote: Hi Karen and Didit, I had a very similar dx as both of you, but only one year earlier. I am done with surgery,chemo and radiation - now on Femara since 6 months. I was also in a clinical trial for Avastin - are you both in this trial? I have heard good prognosis with Avastin. If you are in this trial, then there is one more forum for women in this trial, under "help me get through the treatment"; if not, may be you can ask your oncologist about it. I had dose dense AC (every two weeks) and then Taxol and 36 sessions of rads. AC was harder than Taxol. But it went by fast!! I found it was bearable to have flavoured drinks (chilled). The more I drank, the less was my nausea. Ofcourse, sweet things tasted gross!! But.. we survived and so will you.. there are so many meds to deal with the SE's - all you need to do is tell your oncologist. Do keep us posted.. there are lot of ladies here who can advise you... great support group...Good luck with everything.. Desi.

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2009 11:29AM S3K5 wrote: Hi Di Di, I am taking Femara because I am ER+/PR+ .Femara is an anti-hormone tab, to reduce the amount of hormones our body makes, Â thus preventing recurrence. Some women go on other AI's and Tamoxifen. These do the same thing. Avastin is a blockbuster drug made by Genentech. This has been FDA approved for a lot of stage IV cancers, with good results. Now the trial is to see if it benefits earlier stage cancers (like stage I-III breast cancer). Your oncologist may have more information regarding this trial. Avastin is not a small molecule drug like other chemo drugs - it is protein based and given along with either AC or Taxol. Hope this helps. Glad to know you are doing well on AC. I had surgery before chemo and rads. Good luck, Desi.
Posts.Title: New Comer AsiaYM victoriasecret
